text: We’ll hear arguments next in Number 785, National Labor Relations Board against the Natural Gas Utility District.
Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.

I do not recall from the briefs at the moment Mr. Manoli but does the -- does Tennessee’s law permit private corporations that is a telephone company for example to exercise the right of eminent of domain?
Yes it does.
I wasn’t sure whether they applied with – for Tennessee cases.
If they are Tennessee cases, (Voice Overlap) --
That’s fairly common, isn’t it every where?
Sir?
That’s fairly common, isn’t it?
Yes it is.
The railroads and telephone companies?
Yes, eminent domain is not a unique characteristic of political subdivisions.
You know that’s interesting to be --
Sir?
Any difference between you and your Brother on the other side this morning as to this issue.
The -- I’m not entirely sure if he agrees on that.
(Voice Overlap) but if I can understand --
There is the court below.
In this language he said so in his brief.
The court below of course took it a --
Yes, but there’s no issue between you here today as far as I know.
I had not fully appreciated that.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
Is the utility district a part of what subdivision, it’s not a state agency, right?
It is, if Your Honor please, a subdivision of the state, yes sir.
Are the board members officers of the state?
They are public officials, if Your Honor please.
Public officers, do they take oath?
Yes sir, they would take an oath of office.
They'd take an oath, the same oath that the other state officers take?
I’m not informed on that Your Honor but I know they take an oath before they serve.
What is the oath, you don’t know?
No sir, I do not know that.
Well can you be a state officer, and you don’t take an oath?
Yes sir, you can be a state official.
I just said state officer.
State officer.
I think you would settle for the state official, won’t you?
Yes sir.
How are they compensated?
They receive very nominal compensation Your Honor.
Paid by?
It is paid by the county, by the --
(Inaudible)
No, it’s paid by the district out of its own funds Your Honor.
How often are they selected?
They are selected every two, four and six years.
By the vote of whom?
They are selected originally by the county judge and I would like to state --
(Inaudible)
Vacancies are filled by the members of the board unless there they cannot agree and then they are filled by the county judge.
The county judge then is not primarily a judicial officer?
No sir.
He is more or like a -- what a county judge is in Missouri, for example?
Yes sir.
What is elsewhere called a county commissioner?
Yes sir.
How are the personnel of the district employed?
Excuse me sir.
How are the personnel of the district employed?
The district has a manager and the manager hires and fires and sets the wages.
Do you have a civil service system in Tennessee?
No sir, we do not.
Are these employees treated on the basis comparable to other employees of the county or the cities or are they --
Yes sir.
Mr. Greener, maybe I misunderstood you but I did not understand that the county judge performed that function.
Let me clarify that Your Honor.
Who does the nominating?
The original person seeking to setup the district.
(Voice Overlap)
As we pointed out in our brief, the power to appoint and we have referred to some municipal law in McQuillin, includes the power not to appoint.
How do you know?
Your Honor there is an annotation so holding and we have referred to it in the record, in our brief that -- and this is not controverted in this record.
May I ask you of that?
Yes sir.
Are their districts like that at every place in the state?
Yes sir.
The same kind?
No sir.
I was trying to find out really what's behind this controversy.

Your Honor, that I do not know but I will say this that we and also in an answer to the Chief Justice’s remarks earlier, we have districts in Tennessee that provide fire protection, police protection, sewage, natural gas. There are all kinds of services that a district can provide.
Is there any difference in the qualities or the kind in East Tennessee and West Tennessee?
No sir.
Is it covered by general state law or --
Yes sir.
And their election is by general elections, state elections?
Where the commissioners are --
Benton County?
Yes sir, whether commissioners are elected or whether the county judge is elected, they are elected by the qualified voters in the county at a general election.
What happens if you win and what happens if the others win?
Well if Your Honor please --
I’m trying to find out what it’s about.
Well, the board simply cannot order one of these districts to bargain with a labor organization if we prevail and if the board prevails a district would have to bargain with the labor organization.
We’ll recess for lunch now counsel.
Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.
That’s under the Social Security Act Provisions.
Yes sir.
Do you know under what language of that legislation?
Yes sir.
And it says municipal -- excuse me.
(Voice Overlap) – They also are the non-private corporations in that same division.
No sir, I don’t think so.
Well non-profit corporations in Tennessee, are they subjected to the will of the county judge?
Non-profit --
What I’m trying to say is it restricted to Government owned or aren’t they also non-Government owned, non-profit corporations who enjoy the same privilege?
I do not know sir but I believe you are probably right that this benefit may extend to non-profit corporations which may or may not be a municipality.
I just know of several states that have that.
Yes sir, I do not know that for sure.
Mr. Greener, why do you say that? Do you have a special ruling to that effect?
No sir we do not but we have made this contention from the lowest court and it has not been controverted by the board.
And so far as you know it’s never been litigated.
No sir, we do not, it has not.
Well, was it embraced in some allegation in pleadings of some kind?
Yes sir, it was.
No evidence on it, it’s just an undisputed allegation.
The record probably can make have this in it.
What’s the peculiar relevancy of that to the issue?
The only relevance Your Honor is that this is one more of a series of indicia showing this to be a municipality.
As you described as a municipality in any law?
Yes sir.
What benefit do you get from it if it is a municipality?
We get tax exemption.
Well, would that be highly relevant in the question before us?
Yes sir.
What about federal income taxes?
Federal -- no federal income tax either Your Honor.
We can follow through on the federal income tax exemption.
Your Honor, it’s not in the record but they have such an -- they are exempt and yes they do.
Do you have an income tax in Tennessee?
Yes sir but it’s not applicable to this.
They don’t have income, do you?
Yes sir.
Well no wonder he doesn’t pay any income taxes if it has no income.
Well, it also exempt specifically from all state taxation Your Honor by the statute itself.
Is it privately owned?
It’s owned by the citizens of the district.
All of them?
Sir?
All of them?
Yes sir.
You mean it’s fully and completely, publicly owned --
Yes sir.
With no private directors or officers.
No sir, none.
MHas it ever before you proceeded, has it ever been decided whether your client has sovereign immunity as a defendant in a tort action for example.
No sir, I don’t believe it has.
Well, don’t you have some (Inaudible)
They have the right to sue and they sue.
(Inaudible)
They do.
Do you have the doctrine of sovereign immunity in Tennessee?
For torts?
Yes sir, we do.
Or does it -- and then is it applicable when a Government is acting in a proprietary capacity, that’s a distinction we used to have in Ohio --
Yes sir.
I was just curious, thank you.
Yes.
Do you challenge the Government's right if it wished to do so to subject employees of an agency like yours to the National Labor Relations Act?
Yes sir.
I say what if you claim any constitutional exemption?
No sir, it’s statutory.
Does the district have a president?
Sir?
Does the district have a president like a corporation?
No sir, it does not.
Who fixes the range?
The utility district commissioners but they are limited by statute.
To the customers.
Yes sir.

Since you couldn’t conceivably -- the commissioners couldn’t conceivably anticipate precisely their income and their out go, I suppose we can assume that there is some moderate surplus each year which is rebated.
Your Honor that is theoretically the case.
Who paid its deficits?
Sir?
Who has paid its deficits?
The deficits have remained unpaid.
Thank you Mr. Greener.
